{{nowrap|(69 days)}} |time=14:05 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] ([[UTC]]â4) |place=[[Atacama Desert]] near [[CopiapÃ³]], [[Chile]] |coordinates={{coord|27|9|36.73|S|70|29|48.4|W|region:CL-AT_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |first reporter = [[San Esteban Mining Company|{{nowrap|San Esteban}} {{nowrap| Mining Company}}]] |outcome = All 33 trapped miners rescued by government |reported injuries = 0 |reported death(s) = 0 |reported property damage = Total closure and loss {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |inquiries = Under investigation {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |suspects = Under investigation {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |charges = Under investigation {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |convictions = Under investigation {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |litigation = US$2 million lawsuit {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |awards = In litigation {{nowrap|{{As of|2010|8|lc=on}}}}{{Update after|2011}} |website = {{Url|1=http://www.minmineria.cl/574/w3-propertyvalue-2297.html|2=Ministry of Mining, Chile}} |notes=
{{Location map many|Chile|float=center|width=193|caption=Location of the Mina San JosÃ© in Chile |label=[[Mina San JosÃ©]] |position=left |lat=-27.160203 |long=-70.496778 |mark = Flashspot.gif |marksize = 15 |label2=[[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] |position2=left |lat2=-33.4378 |long2=-70.6503 |mark2 = Red pog.svg |marksize = 8 }}
}} The '''2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident''', also known as the "'''Chilean mining accident'''", began in the afternoon of Thursday, 5 August 2010 as a significant [[cave-in]] at the troubled 121-year-old [[San JosÃ© Mine|San JosÃ©]] copper–gold mine. The mine is located deep in the [[Atacama Desert]], one of the driest and harshest regions on earth, about {{convert|45|km|sp=us}} north of [[CopiapÃ³]], in northern [[Chile]], [[South America]]. {{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/23/miners-trapped-alive-chile|title=Chilean miners found alive â but rescue will take four months|author=Haroon Siddique|publisher=The Guardian|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010 | location=London}} The buried men, who became known as "'''Los 33'''" ("The 33"), were trapped {{convert|700|m|ft|sp=us}} underground and about {{convert|5|km|0|sp=us}} from the mine's entrance via spiraling underground service ramps. The mixed crew of experienced miners and technical support personnel subsequently survived for a record 69 days deep underground before their rescue. {{cite web|url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/nacional/2010/08/680-282082-9-onemi-confirma-33-mineros-atrapados-tras-derrumbe-en-yacimiento-en-atacama.shtml|publisher=[[La Tercera]]|title=Onemi confirma a 33 mineros atrapados en yacimiento en Atacama|date=6 August 2010|accessdate=12 October 2010|language=Spanish}}{{cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N08212025.htm |last=Illiano |first=Cesar |title=Rescue near for Chile miners trapped for two months |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2010 |publisher=Reuters AlertNet}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}} Previous geological instability at the old mine and a long record of fines and safety violations for the mine's owners had resulted in a series of accidents, including eight deaths, during the dozen years leading up to this accident.[http://www.asiantribune.com/news/2010/10/14/69-day-trapped-chilean-miners-being-lifted-one-one-safety 69-day trapped Chilean miners being lifted one by one to safety], Asian Tribune, Hallstavik, Sweden, By Gopal Ethiraj, 14 October 2004 As a result of the mine's notorious history, it was originally thought that the workers had probably not survived the collapse or would starve to death before they were found, if ever. The people of Chile had just emerged from the devastating [[2010 Chile earthquake]] and its associated [[2010 Chile earthquake#Chile|tsunami]] less than six months before the accident. The nation's tremendous outpouring of public concern for the plight of the 33 lost miners and the Chilean people's strong empathy for the workers' grief-stricken families led the national government to take over the faltering search and rescue operation from the mine's financially strapped owners, privately held [[San Esteban Mining Company]]. Eight exploratory boreholes were hastily drilled. Seventeen days after the accident, on 22 August, a note written in bold red letters appeared taped to a drill bit when it was pulled to the surface after penetrating an area believed to be accessible to the trapped workers. It read simply ''{{lang|es|"Estamos bien en el refugio, los 33"}}'' (English: ''"We are well in the shelter, the 33"''). The nation of Chile erupted into a wave of euphoria and demanded that Chile's leaders find a way to bring the trapped workers safely home to their waiting families. Once the government rescuers knew that the men were alive, Chile implemented a comprehensive plan to both nurture the workers during their entrapment and to rescue the miners from the depths. It included deployment of three large, international drilling rig teams, nearly every government ministry, the expertise of the [[United State]]s' [[NASA]] space agency and more than a dozen multi-national corporations. After 69 days trapped deep underground, all 33 men were brought safely to the surface on 13 October 2010 over a period of almost 24 hours. After winching the last trapped miner to the surface, the mine rescue paramedics, the best available drawn from multiple national agencies, all still underground, held up a sign for the TV cameras reading ''{{lang|es|"MisiÃ³n cumplida Chile"}}'' (English: "''"Mission accomplished Chile"''), which was seen by a TV/Web audience estimated at more than 1 billion viewers around the world watching the rescue live.[http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2010/10/14/tech-chile-miner-video-stream.html Chilean mine rescue watched by millions online], Canadian Broadcasting Corp., 14 October 2010{{cite news |url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2010/10/13/workers-begin-to-rescue-trapped-chilean-miners/?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=First of 33 trapped miners reaches surface|author= |publisher= CNN |date=12 October 2010|accessdate=12 October 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8058924/Chile-Miners-Rescue-Live.html |title=Chile Miners Rescue: Live |publisher=London Daily Telegraph |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010 | first1=Peter | last1=Hutchison | first2=Bonnie | last2=Malkin | first3=Andy | last3=Bloxham}} All 33 miners were rescued, almost all in good medical condition with no long-term physical effects anticipated. Two miners were found to be suffering from [[silicosis]], one of whom also had [[pneumonia]], while others had dental infections and [[cornea|corneal problems]].{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11489439 | work=BBC News | title=Chile mine rescue | date=13 October 2010}} Three of the men underwent immediate surgery under general anesthesia for their dental problems.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/15/3039578.htm First Chile miners leave hospital] - Australian Broadcasting Corporation (15 October 2010) - Retrieved 18 October 2010 Private donations covered one-third of the [[US$]]20 million cost of the rescue, with the rest coming from the mine owners and the government.{{cite web|url=http://www.wbay.com/Global/story.asp?S=13318937 |title=Chile's textbook mine rescue brings global respect - WBAY-TV Green Bay-Fox Cities-Northeast Wisconsin News |publisher=Wbay.com |date=13 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010}} Various lawsuits and investigations resulting from the accident are still pending as of March 2011. {{TOC left}} {{Graphical timeline |from=-5 |to=90
