{{nowrap|rescued (day 69)}}''']] |note3-at=68 |note3-nudge-left=3 |note4=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Miners post-rescue|{{nowrap|15 Oct: 31 of 33 miners home}}]] |note4-at=71 |note4-nudge-left=6 |note5=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Aftermath of the accident|'''{{nowrap|24 October 2010: 33 miners }}{{nowrap|honored in Santiago, Chile}}''']] |note5-at=80 |note5-nudge-left=6 |note6=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Plan A|30 Aug â 9 Oct: Plan A drilling]] |note6-at=25 |note6-nudge-left=4.75 |note7=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Plan B|5 Sep â 9 Oct: Plan B drilling]] |note7-at=30 |note7-nudge-left=3 |note8=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Plan C|19 Sep â 9 Oct: Plan C drilling]] |note8-at=43 |note8-nudge-left=1.7 |note9=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Survival|'''24 September: {{nowrap|old survival record}}''']] |note9-at=50 |note9-nudge-left=1.7 |note10=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Drilling results|9 October: {{nowrap|drilling complete}}]] |note10-at=59 |note10-nudge-left=1.7 |note11=[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Extraction plans|'''{{nowrap|Operation St. Lorenzo}}''']] |note11-at=62 |note11-nudge-left=3 |caption='''Day 01 = 5 August 2010''' }} {{-}} ==Background== [[File:Sanjosemine ali 2010259 lrg (Annotated).jpg|thumb|right|alt=Satellite photo of the mine area in the Atacama desert.|Satellite image of the {{lang|es|[[San JosÃ© mine]]}} and its surroundings]] {{See also|Mining in Chile}} Chile's long tradition of mining developed during the 20th century and has made the country the world's [[List of countries by copper production|top producer]] of [[copper]].[http://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/economies/Americas/Chile.html Encyclopedia of the Nations] - CHILE - MINING - Copyright Â© 2010 Advameg, Inc. An average of 34 people per year since 2000 have died in mining accidents in Chile, with a high of 43 in 2008, according to figures from the state regulatory agency [[Servicio Nacional de GeologÃ­a y MinerÃ­a de Chile|National Geology and Mining Service]] {{lang-es|Servicio Nacional de GeologÃ­a y MinerÃ­a de Chile}} abbreviated to SERNAGEOMIN).{{cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/27/trapped-chilean-miners-video%20Â© | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Sam | last=Jones | title=Trapped Chilean miners sing national anthem in footage from inside mine | date=27 August 2010}} The mine is owned by the [[San Esteban Mining Company]], ({{lang-es|CompaÃ±Ã­a Minera San Esteban}} abbreviated to ''CMSE''), a company notorious for operating unsafe mines. According to an official with the [[non-profit]] [[Chilean Safety Association]], ({{lang-es|AsociaciÃ³n Chilena de Seguridad}}, also known as ''ACHS'') eight workers have died at the San JosÃ© site in the past 12 years[http://www.thestar.com/news/world/chile/article/873382--from-collapse-to-rescue-inside-the-chile-mine-disaster From collapse to rescue: Inside the Chile mine disaster], Toronto Star, Jennifer Yang, 10 Oct 2010 while CMSE was fined 42 times between 2004 and 2010 for breaching safety regulations.{{cite news|title=Families of trapped Chilean miners to sue mining firm|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/7966590/Families-of-trapped-Chilean-miners-to-sue-mining-firm.html|author=Govan, Fiona, Aislinn Laing and Nick Allen |publisher=London Daily Telegraph|date = 26 August 2010|accessdate=26 August 2010}} The mine was shut down temporarily in 2007 when relatives of a miner killed in an accident sued the company but the mine reopened in 2008{{Cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11102478 |title=Trapped Chile miner's family sues owners and officials |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=27 August 2010 |publisher=BBC News}} despite non-compliance with regulations, a matter that remains under investigation according to [[Senate of Chile|Senator]] Baldo Prokurica.[http://www.nbc26.com/Global/story.asp?S=13048180 "New video gives tour of trapped miners' refuge"] â Associated Press writers â Bradley Brooks and Peter Prengaman â with Federico Quilodran in Copiapo, Eduardo Gallardo in Santiago, and Michael Warren in Buenos Aires, Argentina, contributing to this report. The Associated Press, (NBC26.com) 28 August 2010 â Copyright 2010. Due to budget constraints there were only three inspectors for the [[Atacama Region]]'s 884 mines during the period leading up to the most recent collapse. Prior to the accident, CMSE had ignored warnings over unsafe working conditions in its mines. According to Javier Castillo, secretary of the [[trade union]] that represents San JosÃ©'s miners, the company's management operates "without listening to the voice of the workers when they say that there is danger or risk" . "Nobody listens to us. Then they say we're right. If they would have believed the workers, we would not be lamenting this now," said Gerardo NÃºÃ±ez, head of the union at a nearby Candelaria Norte mine.[http://www.laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=362450&CategoryId=14094 Unions Say Mining Becoming More Dangerous in Chile] [[Latin American Herald Tribune]], 9 August 2010 Chilean copper mine workers are among the highest-paid miners in South America.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/7894761?story_id=7894761|title=A worrying precedent|publisher=The Economist|date=7 September 2006|accessdate=23 August 2010}} Although the accident has called mine safety in Chile into question, serious incidents at large mines are rare, particularly those owned by the state copper mining company, Codelco or by multinational companies. However, smaller mines such as the one at CopiapÃ³ have generally lower safety standards. Wages at the San Jose Mine were around 20% higher than at other Chilean mines due to its poor safety record.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/blogs/americasview/2010/08/chiles_trapped_miners|title=Celebration before a hard slog|publisher=The Economist|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}}[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,716102,00.html The Media Circus at Chile's San JosÃ© Mine] Spiegel Online, 8 September 2010 ==Accident== ===Initial information=== [[File:MSJ.en.svg|thumb|right|440px|alt=Abstract graphic illustration of the underground accident site in the mine with markings, annotations and depths|'''[[Abstract art|Abstract]] diagram of the accident (not to scale; depths are meters [[Above mean sea level|AMSL]])''']] The collapse occurred at 14:00 [[Time in Chile|CLT]] on 5 August 2010, according to CMSE, the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare, the Chilean Undersecretary of Mining and the director of SERNAGEOMIN.{{cite web |author=Vila, Narayan |url=http://www.lanacion.cl/amplio-despliegue-para-rescatar-a-mineros-atrapados/noticias/2010-08-06/210402.html |title=Amplio despliegue para rescatar a mineros atrapados |publisher=[[La NaciÃ³n (Chile)]] |date=7 August 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010}} On the day of the accident, the National Emergencies Office of the Interior Ministry ([[ONEMI]]) (Spanish: ''Oficina Nacional de Emergencias del Ministerio del Interior'') released the names of the 33 trapped miners,{{cite web|author=Navarrete, Camila|url=http://www.radiobiobio.cl/2010/08/06/se-confirman-las-identidades-de-mineros-atrapados-en-mina-san-jose-en-region-de-atacama/|title=Se confirman las identidades de mineros atrapados en mina San JosÃ© en RegiÃ³n de Atacama|publisher=Radio BÃ­o BÃ­o|date=6 August 2010|accessdate=12 October 2010|language=Spanish}} which included retired Chilean footballer [[Franklin Lobos]]. All the miners were Chilean nationals apart from [[Bolivia]]n Carlos Mamani.[http://www.elespectador.com/imagen-220800-estos-son-los-mineros-chilenos-atrapados Estos son los mineros chilenos atrapados] El Espectador, 24 August 2010 [[Laurence Golborne]], Chilean Minister of Mining, was in [[Ecuador]] at the time of the disaster and arrived at the site on 7 August. When the cave-in occurred there were two groups of workers in the mine. The group nearest the entrance escaped immediately without incident. A second group of 33 men was deep inside the mine, including several subcontracted vehicle mechanics who did not normally work deep within the mine.Tim King [http://www.salem-news.com/articles/october122010/chile_rescue.php "LIVE VIDEO: Rescue of Miners in Chile Comes to Fruition"] Salem-News.com, 12 October 2010 A thick dust cloud caused by the rock fall blinded the miners for up to six hours as well as causing lingering eye irritation and burning. ===Trapped group=== Initially the trapped miners tried to escape through the ventilation shaft system, but the ladders required by mining safety codes were missing. These shafts later became inaccessible due to ground movements and could not be used by rescue teams.{{cite news|title=Chile sets sight on escape shaft for trapped miners|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN24255937|author = Soto, Alonso |publisher=Reuters |date = 24 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010}} Despite a stipulation by the authorities following a previous closure that the mine could not be re-opened without the installation of escape ladders, CMSE had failed to install the required equipment by the time of the accident. Many parts of the mine were over 100 years old and access to the depths of the mine's workings were reached by a long, sloping roadway with many irregular spiral turns,[[Channel 4]] British TV program ''Buried Alive: The Chilean Mine Rescue'', 8 pm to 9 pm, Wednesday 27 October 2010 rather than by a vertical [[Shaft mining|mineshaft]] and elevator system. Luis UrzÃºa, the duty shift supervisor, recognized the gravity of the situation and the difficulty involved in any potential rescue attempt. He gathered his men in a secure room called a "[[Mine Rescue Chamber|refuge]]" and organized them and their meager resources to ensure long-term survival. Experienced miners were sent out to assess the situation, men with important skills were given key roles while numerous other measures were taken to maximize the chances of surviving the disaster.{{cite news|title=Luis Urzua, the foreman keeping hope alive for Chile's trapped miners|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/05/luis-urzua-chile-trapped-miners|author = Franklin, Jonathan |publisher=The Observer |date = 5 September 2010|accessdate=14 October 2010 | location=London}} ==Search and rescue attempts== ===Ventilation shaft=== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© -PiÃ±era con mensaje de mineros atrapados.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Color image of President PiÃ±era displaying the message in a plastic document protector sent by the miners with Mining Minister Golborne|President PiÃ±era holds the message sent by the miners along side Mining Minister Golborne (red jacket, blue shirt)]] [[Mine rescue|Rescuers]] attempted to bypass the rockfall at the main entryway through alternative passages but found each route blocked by fallen rock or threatened by ongoing rock movement. After a second collapse on 7 August, rescuers were forced to use heavy machinery while trying to gain access via a ventilation shaft.Ross Lydall [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23887231-tears-of-joy-as-chile-miners-are-finally-rescued.do "Tears of joy as Chile miners complete their great escape"] London Evening Standard, 13 October 2010 Concerns that additional attempts to pursue this route would cause further geological movement halted attempts to reach the trapped miners through previously existing shafts and other means to find the men were sought.{{cite web |url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/ministro-golborne--el-acceso-por-la-chimena-ya-no-es-una-opcion/prontus_nots/2010-08-07/160054.html |title=Ministro Golborne: El acceso por la chimenea ya no es una opciÃ³n |publisher=[[Radio Cooperativa (Chile)]] |date=7 August 2010 |language=Spanish |accessdate=12 October 2010}} The accident happened soon after sharp criticism of the government's handling of the major [[2010 Chile earthquake|Chilean earthquake]] and tsunami. In light of the worsening situation and amidst the increasing concern of the Chilean populace, who were deeply sympathetic to the miners plight and that of their families, [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era|President PiÃ±era]] cut short an official trip and returned to Chile in order to visit the mine.{{cite web |url=http://www.latercera.com/noticia/politica/2010/08/674-282431-9-pinera-vuelve-a-chile-y-viajara-a-zona-del-accidente-en-la-mina-san-jose.shtml |title=PiÃ±era vuelve a Chile y viajarÃ¡ a zona del accidente en la mina San JosÃ© |publisher=[[La Tercera]] |date=7 August 2010 |language=Spanish |accessdate=12 October 2010}} ===Exploratory boreholes=== [[Drill#Rotary hammer drill|Percussion drills]] were used to create eight exploratory [[boreholes]] about {{convert|16|cm|sp=us}} in diameter in an attempt to find the miners.[http://articles.cnn.com/2010-08-22/world/chile.miners_1_miners-rescuers-rescue-workers?_s=PM:WORLD After 17 days, trapped Chilean miners send note they're alive], CNN News, 22 August 2010 Out-of-date mine shaft maps complicated rescue efforts and several boreholes drifted off-target{{cite news|publisher=[[London Daily Telegraph]]|title=Camp Hope families wait in Chile's Atacama Desert for trapped miners|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/7969542/Camp-Hope-families-wait-in-Chiles-Atacama-Desert-for-trapped-miners.html|accessdate=28 August 2010|date=28 August 2010|author=Sherwell, Philip}} due to the extreme drilling depth and the notoriously [[Underground mining (hard rock)|hard rock]] that exacerbated the drill's tendency to drift. On 19 August, 14 days into the rescue operation, one of the probes reached a space where the miners were believed to be trapped but found no signs of life.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE67M0G820100823|title=Timeline: Trapped Chilean miners|publisher=Reuters|date=22 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}} The search and rescue operation was led by Engineer AndrÃ© Sougarret, head of the state-owned Codelco [[El Teniente|El Teniente Mine]].[http://diario.latercera.com/2010/08/23/01/contenido/pais/31-36352-9-andre-sougarret-yo-dependo-de-lo-que-diga-el-presidente-pero-hasta-ahora-me.shtml AndrÃ© Sougarret: "Yo dependo de lo que diga el Presidente, pero hasta ahora me quedo"] (Spanish) La Tercera, F. Fuentes/M. RodrÃ­guez/C. Pizarro,undated ===Discovery=== [[File:Estamos bien los 33.svg|thumb|left|alt=Image of hand written note in Spanish, reading "Estamos bien en el refugio, los 33" (English: "We are well in the shelter, the 33")|Digital representation of the note sent by the miners (English: "We are well in the shelter, the 33")]] On 22 August at 07:15 CLT, the eighth borehole, drilled by [[TerraServices]], using a [[Schramm Inc.|Schramm]] T685 WS drill equipped with a {{frac|6|1|2}}-inch (17 cm) [[drill bit]], broke through into the mine.[http://www.pottsmerc.com/articles/2010/10/14/news/srv0000009663112.txt Chesco company proud to help with Chilean miner rescue], The Mercury, Pennsylvania (US), Brian McCullough, 14 October 2010 At a depth of {{convert|688|m|sp=us}} it reached a ramp, about {{convert|20|m|sp=us}} from an emergency shelter where it was thought that the miners had taken refuge.{{cite web|url=http://www.lavoz.com.ar/noticias/sucesos/chile-sonda-llega-cerca-de-mineros-atrapados |title=Chile: Sonda llega cerca de mineros atrapados|publisher=La Voz|language=Spanish|date=22 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}} For days the miners had heard drills approaching and had prepared notes which they attached to the tip of the drill with insulation tape when it poked into their space. The drilling engineers had thought they heard tapping on the drill bit, but they were surprised to discover the notes when the drill bit was pulled out, as the miners had survived for 17 days, much longer than anyone had expected.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/24/2991575.htm?section=world |title=Aussie drill expert called to Chile mine rescue|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)]]|author=McMurtrie, Craig|date=24 August 2010|accessdate=24 August 2010}} At 15:17 [[Time in Chile|CLDT]], President PiÃ±era showed the media a note written on a piece of paper with a red marker that confirmed the miners were alive. The note read: {{lang|es|"Estamos bien en el refugio, los 33"}} (English: "We are well in the shelter, the 33"). The words became the motto of the miners' survival and the rescue effort, and appeared on websites, banners and t-shirts.{{cite news |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE67L1H620100822 |title=Trapped Chile miners alive but long rescue ahead |publisher=Reuters |date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=13 October 2010 }} Hours later, video cameras sent down the borehole made contact with the men, capturing the first grainy, black-and-white, silent images of the skinny, dirty, shirtless and unshaven miners.{{cite news|title=Miners trapped in Chile mine for 17 days 'are alive'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11054376|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=22 August 2010| date=22 August 2010}} {{-}} ==Survival== {{Main|Miners' survival during 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident}} [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - first view of chilean miners - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Partially out of focus, black and white video capture of first view of face of one of the trapped miners|This iconic image was the world's first view of the trapped miners after a video camera was lowered down the borehole.]] The trapped miner's emergency shelter had an area of {{convert|50|sqm|sp=us}} with two long benches, but ventilation problems had led them to move out into a tunnel. As well as the shelter, they had access to some {{convert|2|km|sp=us}} of galleries in which to move around.{{cite news|title=Chilean miners' families pitch up at Camp Hope|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/25/chilean-miners-families-camp-hope|author = Franklin, Jonathan |publisher=The Guardian |date = 25 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010 | location=London}} Food supplies were limited and each of the men had lost an average of {{convert|8|kg|sp=us}} by the time they were discovered.{{cite news|title=Chile secures lifeline to trapped miners, sends aid|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE67L1NU20100824|author = Soto, Alonso|publisher=Reuters|date = 24 August 2010|accessdate=24 August 2010}} Although emergency supplies were intended to last only two or three days, through careful rationing they were made to last for two weeks, running out just before the men were discovered.{{cite news|title=Trapped Chile miners give video tour of confinement|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11106045|author =|publisher=BBC News|date = 27 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010}} After leaving hospital, miner Mario SepÃºlveda said "All 33 trapped miners, practicing a one-man, one-vote democracy, worked together to maintain the mine, look for escape routes and keep up morale. We knew that if society broke down we would all be doomed. Each day a different person took a bad turn. Every time that happened, we worked as a team to try to keep the morale up." He also said that some of the older miners helped to support the younger men but all have taken an oath of silence not to reveal certain details of what happened, particularly during the early weeks of desperation.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8069092/PIX-AND-PUBLISH-Freed-miner-reveals-darkest-days.html Freed Chile miner Mario Sepulveda reveals darkest days], London Daily Telegraph, 17 October 2010 ===Videos sent to the surface=== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Trapped miners before rescue - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|right|alt=slightly grainy color video capture image showing the dirty and sweaty, slightly malnourished condition of the miners|Video capture image showing the condition of the miners after 17 days trapped below ground]] In late August, 28 of the 33 miners appeared in a 40 minute video recorded using a mini-camera delivered by the government using ''palomas'' ("doves", referring to their role as carrier pigeons), 5-foot-long (1.5 m) blue plastic capsules. The footage showed most of the men in good spirits and reasonably healthly, though they had all lost weight.[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/28/world/americas/28chile.html Video of the Trapped Chilean Miners Stirs a Country's Emotions], The New York Times, Alexei Barrionnuevo, 27 August 2010 The men appeared mainly bare chested and bearded. They were all covered with a sheen of sweat resulting from the high heat and humidity of the mine at that depth. Several of the miners looked very thin and some were camera shy. The host, SepÃºlveda, avoided specifics about the health of the men and used the vague term "complicated" to refer to their situation. He did however work to maintain an upbeat attitude and insisted that things were looking brighter for the trapped men. The video generally portrays a positive, light atmosphere. ===Leadership=== "It's been a bit of a long shift," said foreman Luis UrzÃºa, a man whose level-headedness and gentle humor is credited with helping keep the miners under his charge focused on survival during their 70-day underground ordeal. In his first audio contact with officials on the surface, UrzÃºa kept his cool. He glossed over the hunger and despair he and his men felt, saying: "We're fine, waiting for you to rescue us."[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/bf7e22e4-d897-11df-8e05-00144feabdc0.html Man in the News: Luis UrzÃºa], Financial Times, London, Jude Webber and John Paul Rathbone, 15 October 2010[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/oct/14/chile-miner-luis-urzua-interview Chile miners: Rescued foreman Luis UrzÃºa's first interview], The Guardian (UK), Rory Carroll and Jonathan Franklin, 14 October 2010[http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2010/09/07/2003482273 Chilean mine foreman works heroically to keep hope alive], Taipei Times, China, Jonathan Franklin, 7 September 2010 UrzÃºa credited majority decision-making for the trapped men's good ''esprit de corps'' and dedication to their common goal. "You just have to speak the truth and believe in democracy", he said. "Everything was voted on ... We were 33 men, so 16 plus one was a majority." 54-year-old UrzÃºa was the last man out after 70 long days trapped below the Atacama desert. Following the collapse of the mine on 5 August, he had dispatched men to find out what had happened and see if escape was possible, but they could not find an exit route. "We were trying to find out what we could do and what we could not," said UrzÃºa. "Then we had to figure out the food." UrzÃºa tried to instill a philosophical acceptance of fate so they could accept their situation and move on to embrace the essential tasks of survival. ===Key members of the trapped group=== * '''Luis UrzÃºa''' (54), the shift foreman who immediately recognized the gravity of the situation and the difficulty of any rescue attempt. He gathered the men in a secure "refuge" then organized them and their meager resources to cope with a long-term survival situation.{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8058924/Chile-Miners-Rescue-Live.html |title=Chile Miners Rescue: Live |publisher=London Daily Telegraph |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010 | first1=Peter | last1=Hutchison | first2=Bonnie | last2=Malkin | first3=Andy | last3=Bloxham}}{{cite web | last = Sutton | first = Robert I. | title = Boss Luis Urzua and the Trapped Miners in Chile: A Classic Case of a Leadership, Performance, and Humanity | work = Psychology Today | accessdate = 13 October 2010 | date = 6 September 2010 | url = http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/work-matters/201009/boss-luis-urzua-and-the-trapped-miners-in-chile }} Just after the incident, he led three men to scout the tunnel. After confirming the situation, he made detailed maps of the area to aid the rescue effort. He directed the underground aspects of the rescue operation and coordinated closely with engineers on the surface over the teleconference links. {{cite news | last = Franklin | first = Jonathan | title = Luis UrzÃºa, the foreman keeping hope alive for Chile's trapped miners | work = The Guardian | accessdate = 13 October 2010 | date = 5 September 2010 | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/05/luis-urzua-chile-trapped-miners | location=London }} *'''Florencio Ãvalos''' (31), second in command of the group, assisted UrzÃºa organizing the men. Because of his experience, physical fitness and emotional stability, he was selected as the first miner to ride the rescue capsule to the surface in case of complications during the 15 minute ascent in the claustrophobic shaft. Naturally shy, he served as the camera operator for videos sent up to the miner's families. He was trapped along with his younger brother Renan. * '''Yonni Barrios''' (50), became the medic of the trapped miners, monitoring their health, giving vaccinations, and providing detailed medical reports to the team of doctors on the surface. His fellow miners jokingly referred to him as "[[Dr. House]]", an American TV medical drama character.{{cite news|title=Chile miners must move tons of rocks in own rescue|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100829/ap_on_re_la_am_ca/lt_chile_mine_collapse| author = Prengaman, Peter |publisher=Yahoo! News| agency=Associated Press|date=29 August 2010|accessdate=13 October 2010}}{{Dead link|date=February 2011}} * '''Mario GÃ³mez''' (63), the eldest miner, became the religious leader of the group, organizing a chapel with a shrine containing statues of saints as well as aiding counseling efforts by psychologist on the surface. * '''JosÃ© HenrÃ­quez''' (54), a preacher and a miner for 33 years, he served as the miners' pastor and organized daily prayers. * '''Mario SepÃºlveda''' (40), served as the energetic host of the miner's video journals that were sent to the surface to reassure the world that they were doing well. The local media dubbed him "Super Mario" after the [[Super Mario Bros.]] video game for his energy, wit and humor.[http://www.el-nacional.com/www/site/p_contenido.php?q=nodo/160022/Mundo/S%C3%BAper-Mario-Sep%C3%BAlveda-se-convierte-en-estrella-del-rescate-de-los-mineros "SÃºper Mario" SepÃºlveda se convierte en estrella del rescate de los mineros] El Nacional, 13 October 2010[http://www.cadena3.com/contenido/2010/10/14/63721.asp "El hermano de Mario SepÃºlveda destacÃ³ el buen humor del minero"] Cadena3, 14 October 2010 *'''Ariel Ticona''' (29), served as the group's communications specialist, maintaining the underground portion of the telephone and [[videoconferencing]] systems sent down by the surface team. ==Health of the trapped miners== {{main|Miners' health issues during 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident}} [[File:480382main miners2.jpg|thumb|right|alt=a color photograph of the topside opening of one of the two narrow tubes and hardware used to deliver supplies to the miners 2,000 feet below|One of the two tubes used to deliver supplies to the miners 2,000 ft below]] On 23 August, the first voice contact was made with the miners. Doctors reported that the miners had been provided with a 5% glucose solution and a drug to prevent stomach ulcers caused by food deprivation.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiobiobio.cl/2010/08/23/mineros-confirman-que-estan-en-perfecto-estado-de-salud-tras-contacto-por-citofono/ |title=CMineros confirman que estÃ¡n en perfecto estado de salud tras contacto por citÃ³fono|publisher=Radio BioBio|language=Spanish|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}} Material was sent down the mine in ''palomas'', which took an hour to reach the miners.{{cite news|title=Trapped Chile miners receive food and water|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11064687|publisher=BBC News|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=23 August 2010}}{{cite news|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|title=Chile miners face four-month wait for rescue|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38807555/ns/world_news-americas/38813447|accessdate=24 August 2010|date=23 August 2010|agency=[[Associated Press]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5sEM67Dmo|archivedate=24 August 2010}} Delivery of solid food began a few days later.{{cite news|title=NASA helping in historic rescue of trapped Chilean miners|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/27/AR2010082704867.html| author = Franklin, Jonathan|publisher=The Washington Post|date=27 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010}} Relatives were permitted to write letters, but were asked to keep them optimistic. Out of concern for their morale, rescuers were reluctant to tell the miners that in the worst-case scenario, the rescue might take months, with an eventual extraction date close to Christmas. However on 25 August the trapped men were fully briefed on the projected timeline for their rescue and the complexity of the plans involved. The mining minister later reported that the men took the potentially negative news very well.{{cite news|title=Chile's trapped miners told rescue could take months|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11092343| author = |publisher=BBC News| date=25 August 2010|accessdate=25 August 2010}} Rescue workers and consultants described the miners as a very disciplined group. Psychologists and doctors worked alongside the rescue teams to ensure the miners kept busy and mentally focused. The men below ground confirmed their ability to contribute to the rescue operation, saying "There are a large number of professionals who are going to help in the rescue efforts from down here."{{cite news|title=Chile miners give video tour of cave|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/7968125/Chile-miners-give-video-tour-of-cave.html| author = Laing, Aislinn and Nick Allen |publisher=London Daily Telegraph| date=27 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010 }} Psychologists believed that the miners should have a role in their own destiny as it was important to maintain motivation and optimism.[http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/World/Story/A1Story20101011-241721.html Daily rigors of underground life to end for Chile miners], AsiaOne News, AFP with Gael Favennec, 11 October 2010Martyn McLaughlin [http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/news/Trapped-miners-told-39work-24.6502622.jp Trapped miners told: 'work 24 hour shifts and remove 4,000 tons of rock], The Scotsman, 31 August 2010Fiona Govan [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/7980068/Trapped-miners-form-micro-society-to-keep-them-sane.html Trapped miners form micro-society to keep them sane], London Daily Telegraph,3 September 2010Victor Herrero [http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2010-08-26-chileminers26_ST_N.htm To relieve miners' hell: Latrine, books, antidepressants?], USA Today, 26 August 2010 Sanitation became an important issue in the hot, humid environment underground, and the miners took steps to maintain hygiene throughout their ordeal.Jonathan Franklin [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/09/chilean-miners-typical-day Chilean miners: A typical day in the life of a subterranean miner], The Guardian, 9 September 2010 Environmental and safety issues were also a primary concern. Chilean Health Minister [[Jaime MaÃ±alich]] stated, "The situation is very similar to the one experienced by astronauts who spend months on end in the International Space Station."{{cite web|title=Get us out of underground 'hell,' Chile miners plead|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hHejkzmj_dWqXSObe-VR3LGdt9ag| author = |publisher=Agence France-Presse |date=25 August 2010|accessdate=25 August 2010}} On 31 August, a team from [[NASA]] in the United States arrived in Chile to provide assistance. The team included two physicians, one psychologist, and an engineer.{{cite web|title=NASA Provides Assistance to Trapped Chilean Miners|url=http://www.nasa.gov/news/chile_assistance.html| author = |publisher=NASA |date=1 September 2010|accessdate=2 September 2010}} After the rescue, Dr. Rodrigo Figueroa, chief of the Trauma Stress and Disaster unit of the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile]], said there were serious shortcomings in the censorship of letters to and from miners' relatives above ground and in the monitoring of activities they could undertake, as being underground has suddenly turned them back into "babies". Nevertheless the natural strength of "The 33" kept them alive, and their natural organization into teams as a response to disaster was also part of the innate human response to threat. Figuero went on to say that as the miners' sound minds had seen them through, they would continue to be tested as they resumed life above ground.{{Clarify|date=March 2011}}[http://www.santiagotimes.cl/i/90-miners-special/20025-miners-rescue-in-chile-an-inspiring-note-were-ok-all-33 Miners' Rescue In Chile: An Inspiring Note: We're OK, All 33 (Special Report Excerpt)(English)], The Santiago Times, Kara Frantzich and Ricardo Pommer ==Religious aspects== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Mass at Campamento Esperanza - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|right|alt= A color photo of a priest offering mass in a white tent with dirt floor for the workers and family members at San Jose Mine| Catholic priest offering Mass in a large white tent with a dirt floor for the family members at Camp Hope at the San Jose Mine near Copiapo, Chile|Mass for the family members in Campamento Esperanza at San JosÃ© Mine near CopiapÃ³, Chile]] The trapped miners, most of whom were [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]], asked for religious items, including Bibles, crucifixes, [[Rosary|rosaries]], and statues of the [[Virgin Mary]] and other saints to be sent down to them.Sibley, Robert, [http://www.ottawacitizen.com/opinion/Reborn+from+belly+Earth/3669061/story.html Reborn from the belly of the Earth: The Chilean miners could well look back on their ordeal as an experience that revealed something of their soul]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}, Ottawa Citizen, 14 October 2010 After [[Pope Benedict XVI]] sent each man a rosary, these were brought to the mine by the Archbishop of Santiago, Cardinal [[Francisco Javier ErrÃ¡zuriz Ossa]] in person.[http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/holy-father-gives-thanks-for-rescue-of-chilean-miners/ "Holy Father gives thanks for rescue of Chilean miners"], Catholic News Agency, 13 October 2010 After three weeks in the mine, one man who was [[Civil marriage|civilly married]] to his wife 25 years earlier asked her to enter into a [[Catholic marriage|sacramental marriage]].{{cite news | url = http://articles.cnn.com/2010-08-30/world/chile.miners.love.story_1_miners-chile-rescue-workers?_s=PM:WORLD | work=CNN | title=How will trapped Chile miners cope? | date=23 August 2010}} The men set up a makeshift chapel in the mine, and Mario GÃ³mez, the eldest miner, spiritually counseled his companions and led daily prayers. Among the miners, a number attributed religious significance to events. Mario SepÃºlveda said, "I was with God, and with the Devil -- and God took me." MÃ³nica Araya, the wife of the first man rescued, Florencio Ãvalos, noted: "We are really religious, both my husband and I, so God was always present. It is a miracle, this rescue was so difficult, it's a grand miracle."{{cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/oct/13/chilean-miners-rescued-health | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Jonathan | last1=Franklin | first2=Rory | last2=Carroll | title=Chilean miners: 'We never lost faith. We knew we would be rescued' | date=13 October 2010}} As one story in the UK Daily Mail reported, "A deep religious faith powered this rescue; miners and families and rescuers alike believe their prayers were answered."{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1320336/Chile-Rescue-The-Devil-God-human-spirit-triumphed.html?ito=feeds-newsxml | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Bel | last=Mooney | title=God and the Devil were in that mine. But it was God - and the human spirit - that triumphed | date=14 October 2010}} Both government representatives and the Chilean public have repeatedly credited [[Divine Providence]] with keeping the miners alive while the Chilean public viewed their subsequent rescue as a miracle.Pappas, Stephanie, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39658360/ns/health-behavior/ How 69 Days underground affects spirituality], MSNBC, 14 October 2010 Chile's president SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era stated, "When the first miner emerges safe and sound, I hope all the bells of all the churches of Chile ring out forcefully, with joy and hope. Faith has moved mountains." When Esteban Rojas stepped out of the rescue capsule, he immediately knelt on the ground with his hands together in prayer then raised his arms above him in adoration.Leichman, Aaron J., [http://www.christianpost.com/article/20101013/prayers-persist-as-world-witnesses-rescue-of-chilean-miners/ Prayers Persist as World Witnesses Rescue of Chilean Miners], The Christian Post, 13 October 2010 His wife then wrapped a tapestry bearing the image of Mary around him as they hugged and cried. ==Tent city and the families== {{Lang|es|''Campamento Esperanza''}} (Camp Hope) was a [[tent city]] that sprang up in the desert as word of the mine's collapse spread. At first, relatives gathered at the mine entrance and slept in cars as they waited and prayed for word on the rescue operation's progress. As days turned into weeks, friends brought them tents and other camping supplies to provide shelter from the harsh desert climate. The encampment grew with the arrival of friends and relatives, additional rescue and construction workers, and members of the media. Government ministers held regular briefings for the families and journalists at the camp. "We're not going to abandon this camp until we go out with the last miner left", said MarÃ­a Segovia, "There are 33 of them, and one is my brother".Federico QuilodrÃ¡n (AP) [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38830593/ns/world_news-americas Dinner for Chile miners â 2 spoonfuls of tuna], MSNBC.com, 24 August 2010Reygadas Children [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11136021 Chile miners: Family's diary], BBC News, August to October 2010 Many members of the miners' families at Camp Hope were devout Catholics who prayed almost constantly for the men.{{cite news | url = http://af.reuters.com/article/metalsNews/idAFN1411723720101014?sp=true | work=Reuters | title=Joyous families end long vigil at Chile's "Camp Hope" | date=14 October 2010}} As they waited, worried families erected memorials to the trapped men, lit candles and prayed. On a nearby hill overlooking the mine, the families placed 32 Chilean and one Bolivian flag to represent their stranded men. Small shrines were erected at the foot of each flag and amongst the tents, pictures of the miners, religious icons and statues of the Virgin Mary and patron saints.{{cite news | url = http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/09/faith-plays-key-role-for-trapped-chilean-miners-families/ | work=CNN | title=Faith plays key role for trapped Chilean miners, families|date=9 September 2010}} MarÃ­a Segovia, the elder sister of DarÃ­o Segovia, became known as {{Lang|es|''La Alcaldesa''}} (the Mayoress) for her organizational skills and outspokenness.Vanessa Buschschluter [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11513534 High heels and hairdos: Chile countdown begins], BBC News, 11 October 2010 As the families became more organized, the government took steps to provide some comforts, eventually providing a more private area for the relatives to avoid constant interrogation by the energetic press corps. Infrastructure such as a kitchen, canteen area, sanitary facilities and security were later added. Bulletin boards sprouted up and the local government established shuttle bus stops. Over time a school house and children's zones were built while volunteers worked to help feed the families. Clowns entertained the children and organizations provided emotional and spiritual comfort to the waiting families.Moises Avila Roldan [http://www.smh.com.au/world/miners-no-longer-in-dark-rescue-months-away-20100826-13u8n.html Miners no longer in dark: rescue months away], Sydney Morning Herald, 27 August 2010 Police and soldiers were brought in from Santiago to help maintain order and security, with some patrolling the desert perimeter on horseback. In many respects the camp gradually grew into a small city.Simon Romero,[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/13/world/americas/13scene.html?scp=12&sq=camp%20hope%20chilean%20miners%20families&st=cse Humanity Is Drawn to Scene of Rescue], NY Times, 12 October 2010Matthew Moffett [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB20001424052748704147804575455511399879190.html Underground Dreams: Beer, Hugs and Weddings]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}, Wall Street Journal, 28 August 2010 {{Dead link|date=February 2011}} ==Rescue plans== {{Main|Rescue plans for 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident}} [[File:Ellgaard, Das Wunder von Lengede, 1963.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A watercolor painting of the Dahlbusche Bomb, the 1963 precedecessor of the phoenix used in Wunder von Lengede |Miner rescued with a [[Dahlbusch Bomb]], the 1963 predecessor of the ''FÃ©nix'', ''[[Wunder von Lengede]]'', artist depiction (1963) by [[Helmuth Ellgaard]]]] Exploratory bore holes were used to locate the trapped miners, with several of these subsequently used to supply the men logistically. The Chilean government developed a comprehensive rescue plan modeled on the successful 2002 US [[Quecreek Mine Rescue]], itself based on the 1963 German [[Wunder von Lengede]] rescue operation. Both previous rescues had used a "rescue pod" or capsule to winch trapped miners to the surface one-by-one. Chilean rescue crews planned to use at least three drilling technologies to create bore holes wide enough to raise the miners in custom-designed rescue pods as quickly as possible. "The mine is old and there is concern of further collapses," Henry Laas, managing director of Murray & Roberts Cementation, one of the companies involved in the rescue operation, said, "The rescue methodology therefore has to be carefully designed and implemented."[http://www.santiagotimes.cl/i/90-miners-special/20024-miners-rescue-in-chile-an-unprecendent-rescue-begins Miners's Recue In Chile: An Unprecendent Rescue Begins (Special Report)(English)], The Santiago Times, Dominique Farrell and Dustin Zarnikow ===Drilling plans=== Large escape boreholes were drilled concurrently using several types of equipment provided by multiple international corporations and based on three different access strategies. When the first (and only) escape shaft reached the miners, the three plans in operation were: # '''Plan A''', the Strata 950 (702 meter target depth at 90Â°), # '''Plan B''', the Schramm T130XD (638 meter target depth at 82Â°), # '''Plan C''', a RIG-421 drill (597 meter target depth at 85Â°).Page 5, [http://www.minmineria.gov.cl/574/articles-7093_recurso_2.pdf San JosÃ© Mine Rescue Operation] presentation, Ministry of Mining, Republic of Chile. ====Plan A==== Used an [[Australia]]n built [[Strata 950]] model [[raise borer]][http://www.ruc.com.au/docs/950_specs.pdf Model 950 Strata Raisebore Machine - Drill Rig Specifications PDF], RUC Cementation Mining Contractors, (English) type [[drilling rig]] often used to create circular shafts between two levels of a mine without using [[explosives]]. Provided by [[South African]] mining company [[Murray & Roberts]], the drill had recently finished creating a shaft for Codelco's Andina copper mine in Chile and was immediately transferred to the San JosÃ© Mine. Since it weighed {{convert|31|ST|MT|sp=us}}, the drill had to be shipped in pieces on a large truck convoy. The Strata 950 was the first of the three drills to begin boring an escape shaft. If the pilot hole had been completed, further drilling would have caused rock debris to fall down the hole, obviating the need for the miners to remove the debris.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11089726 Rescuers face tough challenge to save Chile miners], BBC News, Adrian Brown, 26 August 2010{{cite news|title=Rescuers face tough challenge to save Chile miners|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11089726| author = Brown, Adrian |publisher=BBC News| date=26 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010}} ====Plan B==== Plan B involved a Schramm Inc. T130XD air core drill owned by Geotec S.A. (a Chilean-American joint venture drilling company) that was chosen by Drillers Supply SA (the general contractor of Plan B) to widen one of the three 5.5 inches (14 cm) boreholes that were already keeping the miners supplied with palomas. Internationally, the drills are used to drill top holes for the oil and gas industry and for mineral exploration and water wells This system employed Chilean Drillers Supply SA (DSI) personnel, Mijali Proestakis G.M. and Partner, Igor Proestakis Tech Mgr and Greg Hall C.E.O. (who joined his team on site for the last eight days of drilling) and their 7" drill pipe air core drill, a team of American drillers from Layne Christensen Co. and specialized Down-The-Hole drilling hammers from Center Rock, Inc., of Berlin, Pennsylvania. Center Rock's president and personnel from DSI Chile were present on site for the 33 days of drilling. While the Schramm rig, built by privately held Schramm, Inc. of West Chester, Pennsylvania, was already on the ground in Chile at the time of the mine collapse, additional drilling equipment was flown from the United States to Chile by United Parcel Service. The drill's percussion-technology [[hammer drill]] can drill at more than {{convert|40|m|ft|sp=us}} a day by using four hammers instead of one.{{cite web|title=Center Rock Drill Breaks Through to Trapped Chilean Miners|url=http://www.forconstructionpros.com/print/Equipment-Today/Featured-Equipment-Today-Online-Articles/Center-Rock-Drill-Breaks-Through-to-Trapped-Chilean-Miners/5FCP18070|publisher=For Construction Pros|work=Cygnus|date = 11 October 2010 |accessdate=13 October 2010}}[http://www.airdrill.com.au/images/Airdrill_SchrammT130XD.pdf Schramm Airdrill T130XD Rig Specifications PDF], Schramm Inc.[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/7246077.html 'Plan B' rises to the top for miners], Houston Chronicle (US), Zain Shauk, 13 October 2010 The Schramm T-130 was directed to bore toward the workshop, a space that was accessible by the miners. The T-130 became operational on 5 September and worked in three stages. First, it needed to enlarge the 5.5 inches (14 cm) hole to a 12 inches (30 cm) hole. It then needed to drill the 12 inches (30 cm) hole into a 28 inches (71 cm) diameter hole. âIf we tried to drill from a 5.5 inches (14 cm) hole to a 28 inches (71 cm) hole, the torque would be too high and it would ... put the drill bits under too much pressure,â said Schramm, Inc. Latin American Regional Manager, Claudio Soto. However by reusing the same hole, there was still added pressure on the drill. Delays occurred because of issues with the neck of the drills caused by the angle of the drilling. Rescuers couldnât drill vertically since that would require placing the heavy rig on the unstable ground where the cave in had happened. And the rescuers also had to avoid drilling into the production tunnels that wind above the shelter. Soto added, during the rescue, âItâs a difficult hole. Itâs curved and deep. The hard rock has proven to be abrasive and has worn out the steel of the drill.â The fine rock debris, known as cuttings, fell down the pilot hole; an estimated 500 kilograms (1,100 lb) of rocks fell down every hour. Working in shifts 24 hours a day, the miners had to keep the passage clear with the industrial-sized battery-powered sweepers, shovels and wheel barrows trapped in the mine with them.[21] The miners had to remove on their own a total mass of drilling cuttings estimated at up to 700 metric tons (770 short tons), considering a borehole diameter of 70 centimeters (28 in), with a depth of 688 meters (2,257 ft) and a rock density of 2.7 tons per cubic meter.[22][12] Its first delay was caused by it hitting a metal bar in an old working and wrecking.[23] The wrecked drill bit was retrieved by sending down a steel tube called a "spider", whose end was cut into 8 long teeth. When the spider reached the obstruction, its 8 teeth went down around the drill bit, and on further pressure bent in below the drill bit, holding it, and it was hauled to the surface. The second delay was caused by the replacement drill bit wearing out. As the drill drilled down, the spoil fell down the pilot hole and the trapped miners had to clear it away, using a front loader, fueled with diesel sent down via one of the supply holes. ====Plan C==== {{Infobox News event |notes='''Drilling Results''' {{Progress meter|current=598 |goal=702 |comment1=Plan A, Strata 950 |width=100% |height=20 |display=yes |background2=yellow| bordercolor=black |fontcolor1=red|percent=yes}} {{Progress meter|current=624 |goal=624 |comment1=Plan B, Schramm T130 |width=100% |height=20 |display=yes |background2=green| bordercolor=black |fontcolor1=white|percent=yes}} {{Progress meter|current=372 |goal=597|comment1=Plan C, RIG-421 |width=100% |height=20 |display=yes |background2=yellow| bordercolor=black |fontcolor1=red|percent=yes}} {{-}} }} Operated a powerful Canadian made [[RIG-421]] oil drilling rig operated by Calgary-based [[Precision Drilling Corporation]]. It was the last drill to be added to the rescue process and went into operation on September 19. The rig, normally used for oil and gas well drilling, could theoretically drill a wide enough escape shaft in a single pass without a pilot hole. RIG-421 is a {{convert|43|m|ft|sp=us}} tall [[Drilling rig#Drilling rig classification|Diesel-Electric Triple]] which needed 40 truckloads to bring its components from [[Iquique]], Chile to CopiapÃ³. Chosen for the rescue operation because it can drill large holes deep into the ground and is faster than mining drills,[http://www.precisiondrilling.com/files/PD-Backgrounder.pdf Precision Drilling Corpora. RIG 421 Specifications PDF], Precision Drilling this plan suffered major setbacks due to the difficulty of aiming a large drill at such a small target. Furthermore, the hardness of the rock caused the drill bit to wander from its intended course and it then needed to be removed, resized and repositioned, slowing drilling progress. Many family members of the miners initially had high hopes for this rig, but it was forced to reduce its drill size and so lagged behind the other attempts.{{cite news|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/americas/canadian-effort-to-reach-trapped-chilean-miners-lagging/article1744464 |title=Canadian effort to reach trapped Chilean miners lagging|publisher=Canadian Globe and Mail |date=5 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010 |location=Toronto}}[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/americas/canadian-drillers-content-with-losing-race-to-reach-chilean-miners-for-the-most-part/article1751775 Canadian drillers content with losing race to reach Chilean miners â for the most part], Canadian Globe and Mail, 10 October 2010 ====Drilling results==== At 08:05 CLDT on 9 October 2010, Plan B's Schramm T130XD was the first to reach the trapped miners.[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1313329 La perforadora llegÃ³ al refugio donde se encuentran los mineros], La NaciÃ³n On-Line, 9 October 2010. By 8 October, the Plan A Strata 950's pilot hole had reached only {{percentage|598|702}} of the required depth ({{convert|598|m|sp=us}}), and had not yet started widening its shaft. Plan C's RIG-421, the only machine at the site able to drill a wide enough escape shaft without a pilot hole, reached {{convert|372|m|sp=us}} ({{percentage|372|597}}).{{cite web |url=http://www.minmineria.gov.cl/574/w3-article-8648.html |title=Estado del operativo de rescate|work=Ministerio de MinerÃ­a|publisher=Gobierno de Chile|date=8 October 2010}} The rescue operation was an international effort that involved not only technology, but the cooperation and resources of companies and individuals from around the world, including Latin America, South Africa, Australia, the United States and Canada. NASA specialists helped develop a sophisticated health agenda. Though international participation was critical to success, overall, it was a Chilean-led team effort. As one NASA specialist said during a visit early on in the rescue: "The Chileans are basically writing the book." {{See also|Reaction to the 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Governments |l1=International Government Participation |Reaction to the 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Corporate |l2=International Corporate Participation }} ===Extraction plans=== ====FÃ©nix rescue capsule==== [[File:Esquema Fenix-minero (eng).png|thumb|right|alt=A color diagram depicting the capsule with a miner and text describing the features of the pod |Diagram of the rescue capsule "Fenix" class and the miner equipment used in the CopiapÃ³ accident of 2010 rescue.]] {{Main|FÃ©nix capsules}} While the three drilling operations progressed, technicians worked on building the rescue capsules that would eventually carry the miners to safety.[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/americas/news/article_1590593.php/BACKGROUND-Phoenix-to-pull-Chilean-miners-out-of-the-dark BACKGROUND: "Phoenix" to pull Chilean miners out of the dark ] Monsters and Critics, 11 October 2010.[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/index-1963-46.html ''Das UnglÃ¼ck von Lengede''] [[Der Spiegel]], 13 November 1963, nr. 46, 17. Jahrgang. Several media organizations produced illustrations of the capsules' basic design.[http://abcnews.go.com/meta/search/imageDetail?format=plain&source=http%3A%2F%2Fabcnews.go.com%2Fimages%2FInternational%2F41eb84ca39dc4a2d824e02173f1ac0f9 '''FÃ©nix 2''' Rescue Capsule, side view, opened], ABC News Online Graphic, 14 September 2010[http://abcnews.go.com/meta/search/imageDetail?format=plain&source=http%3A%2F%2Fabcnews.go.com%2Fimages%2FBusiness%2F3b7bc91554324d38aec4208ee4964c47 '''FÃ©nix 2''' Rescue Capsule, top view, opened], ABC News Online Graphic, 14 September 2010[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11527129 Images and description of the ''FÃ©nix 2''] BBC News Online Graphic, 12 October 2010 The steel rescue capsules, dubbed ''[[FÃ©nix capsules|FÃ©nix]]'' (English: [[Phoenix (mythology)|Phoenix]]) were constructed by the Chilean Navy with design input from [[NASA]]. The navy incorporated most of NASA's suggestions and produced three rescue pods: ''FÃ©nix'' 1, 2 and 3, all enhanced versions of the [[Dahlbusch Bomb]] used for mine rescue. ''FÃ©nix'' 1 was presented to journalists and the miners' relatives for their assessment.{{cite web|last=Parker|first=Laura|title= To Design Miners' Escape Pod, NASA Thought Small |url=http://www.aolnews.com/world/article/nasa-engineer-clinton-cragg-thought-small-to-design-rescue-capsule-for-chilean-miners/19667140|work=AOL News|accessdate=10 October 2010}}{{cite web | url = http://www.theengineer.co.uk/design-engineering/news/nasa-designed-capsule-helps-free-chilean-miners/1005467.article | title = NASA-designed capsule helps free Chilean miners | date = 13 October 2010 | publisher = The Engineer | accessdate = 13 October 2010}} The eventual capsule used to rescue the 33 men was the ''FÃ©nix 2'', a device {{convert|54|cm|in|sp=us}} in diameter, narrow enough to avoid hitting the sides of the tunnel. It had retractable wheels to allow for a smoother ride to the surface, an oxygen supply, lighting, video and voice communications, a reinforced roof to protect against rock falls, and an escape hatch with a safety device to allow the passenger to lower himself back down if the capsule became stuck.{{cite news|title=Chile miners: Engineers unveil 21 ins wide rescue capsule |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8002241/Chile-miners-engineers-unveil-21ins-wide-rescue-capsule.html| author = Govan, Fiona |publisher=London Daily Telegraph| date=14 September 2010|accessdate=17 September 2010}} ====Preparations for extraction==== Although drilling finished on 9 October 2010, [[Laurence Golborne]], Chilean Minister of Mining, announced that the rescue operation was not expected to begin before 12 October due to the complex preparatory work required on both the escape shaft and the extraction system site.[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c3220804-d304-11df-9ae9-00144feabdc0.html Chile mine rescue bid nears completion] FT.com, 8 October 2010. These tasks included a borehole inspection to determine how much of the shaft needed [[casing (borehole)|casing]] to prevent rockfalls from jamming the escape capsule. Depending on the shaft casing requirement, installation of the requisite steel pipes could take up to 96 hours. After that, a large concrete platform for the winching rig to raise and lower the capsule had to be poured while the winching rig required assembly. Finally, thorough testing of the capsule and winching system together was required. Golborne also indicated he expected only the first {{convert|100|â|200|m|sp=us}} of the shaft to be cased, a task that could be performed in only 10 hours.{{cite web |url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1312964 |title=El histÃ³rico rescate de los mineros arrancarÃ¡ el martes prÃ³ximo |publisher=La NaciÃ³n On-Line |date=7 October 2010}} In the end, only the first {{convert|56|m|sp=us}} were deemed to require casing. Assembly of a safe lifting system took an additional 48 hours.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11509039 |title=Evacuation of Chile miners 'likely to start Wednesday' |publisher=BBC News|date=10 October 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2010}} Shortly before the extraction phase began, Golborne told reporters that rescuers estimated it would take about an hour to bring each miner to the surface. He therefore expected the lifting phase of the rescue operation to take up to 48 hours.{{cite news|title=Chile escape mine shaft lining 'completed'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11512355|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|work=BBC News|date = 11 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010}} {{See also|Reaction to the 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Governments |l1=International Government Participation |Reaction to the 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident#Corporate |l2=International Corporate Participation }} ==Rescue Operation San Lorenzo== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Manuel GonzÃ¡lez - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Picture of the first rescuer with the Chilean President and fellow rescue workers before entering the rescue capsuleÃ¡le|Manuel GonzÃ¡lez, the first rescuer, is preparing to descend into the [[San JosÃ© Mine]] during ''{{lang|es|"OperaciÃ³n San Lorenzo"}}'']] The rescue effort to retrieve the miners began on Tuesday, 12 October at 19:00 CLDT. Dubbed '''''{{lang|es|OperaciÃ³n San Lorenzo}}''''' (Operation [[Lawrence of Rome|St. Lawrence]]) after the [[patron saint]] [[Lawrence of Rome|of miners]],[http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Operation-St.-Lawrence-a-success,-all-33-Chilean-miners-saved-19716.html Operation St. Lawrence a success, all 33 Chilean miners saved], Asia News, 14 October 2010[http://www.news.tradingcharts.com/futures/7/6/146842267.html "DJ First Of Trapped Chile Miners Returns To Surface In Rescue Ops"]{{dead link|date=March 2011}} Dow Jones Commodities News via Comtex, 12 October 2010 â News provided by COMTEX â Copyright (c) 2010 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. a three-hour initial delay ensued while final safety tests were carried out. At 23:18 CLDT, the first rescuer, Manuel GonzÃ¡lez, an experienced rescue expert and employee of Codelco, was lowered into the mine.[http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/chile-rescue-first-miners-out-after-69-days-undergorund/story-e6frg12c-1225938259664 "Chile Rescue: First miners out after 69 days underground"] â Perth Now â Copyright 2010 â The Sunday Times, 13 October 2010 During the 18-minute descent, the waiting families and surface rescue team members sang the {{lang|es|[[National Anthem of Chile|CanciÃ³n Nacional]]}}, Chile's national anthem. GonzÃ¡lez arrived in the collapsed mine and made contact with the miners at 23:36. ===Extraction=== Although Chilean officials played down the risks of the rescue, the miners still needed to be alert during the ascent in case of problems. As a result, and according to the rescue plan, the first four men to be brought up the narrow shaft were those "deemed the fittest of body and mind".Frank Bajak and Vivian Sequera, with contributions from Michael Warren and Eva Vergara [http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i075ahoJZZkuwcSyRJcUkUDZKuFQD9IQTCOO0?docId=D9IQTCOO0 Nearly half of the miners now free in Chile rescue]{{dead link|date=March 2011}} Associated Press, 13 October 2010; Retrieved 16 October 2010 Thereafter they would be best placed to inform the rescue team about conditions on the journey and report on the remaining miners. Once the four men had surfaced, the rescues proceeded in order of health, with the least healthy brought up from the mine first.{{cite web | url = http://newsofap.com/newsofap-27055-26-chile-eleventh-miner-jorge-galleguillos-rescued.html | title = Chile : Eleventh miner, Jorge Galleguillos, rescued | coauthors = | date = 13 October 2010 | publisher = NewsofAP.com | accessdate = 13 October 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=February 2011}} === Procedure === Six hours before his rescue, each miner switched to a NASA recommended purely liquid diet rich in sugars, minerals and potassium.{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.cl/mineros-comienzan-ayuno-6-horas-antes-del-rescate/noticias/2010-10-11/143649.html |title=Mineros comienzan ayuno 6 horas antes del rescate |publisher=LaNacion.cl |date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010}} Miners also used a girdle around their waists to maintain stable blood pressure, and took an aspirin to avert formation of [[thrombosis|blood clots]].[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-10/trapped-chile-miners-eat-nasa-diet-aspirin-to-prepare-for-coming-rescue.html Trapped Chile Miners Eat NASA Diet, Prepare for Rescue] Bloomberg, Nathan Crooks and Randy Woods, 11 October 2010 â Retrieved 18 October 2010 Each miner was strapped into a harness inside the {{convert|21|in|cm|sp=us}} wide bullet-shaped capsule wearing a green moisture-resistant coveralls[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/international/amigos_welcome_back_from_hell_gEBMzxKf9WVBnZfxSmSWAK Amigos, Welcome Back from Hell â Tears and cheers greet Chilean miners rescued after 68 days] New York Post â Late City Final â 13 October 2010 â page 4. and sunglasses{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2010/10/13/sports-sunglasses-aim-ease-miners-transition/ |title=Sports Sunglasses Can Aid Chilean Miners' Transition |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[Fox News Channel]] |date=13 October 2010|accessdate=14 October 2010}} to avoid retinal damage from initial exposure to harsh lighting on the surface. The capsule included oxygen masks, heart monitors, and video cameras. Once the miner was secure inside the capsule it then ascended at a rate of {{convert|1|m/s|mph|sp=us}}, with an estimated travel time of 9 to 18 minutes. When the capsule surfaced a doctor checked the miner's alertness before he was helped out of the capsule and immediately reunited with a small group of close family members to a round of applause from rescue workers, family members and observers. Throughout the 24 hour long operation, each miner was personally greeted by President PiÃ±era and in many cases his wife too. After this the miner was stretchered to a [[field hospital]] for initial evaluation. As none of the men needed immediate emergency treatment, each was transferred by ambulance to an office building, still on the mine premises, for a private reunion with close family members. Finally, the miners were transferred in groups of four by helicopter to CopiapÃ³ Hospital, {{convert|60|km|mi|sp=us}} away, for a 24â48 hour period of medical observation and treatment. While the previously rescued miners received medical treatment, the capsule repeated its descent in readiness to lift the next man to the surface. ===Rescue=== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Luis UrzÃºa - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Color image of the mining leader and the Chilean President leading rescue workers in a rendition of the Chilean anthem.|Luis UrzÃºa, the leader of the trapped miners and the last of the 33 to be lifted to freedom, celebrates with President PiÃ±era at the [[San JosÃ© Mine]], during ''{{lang|es|"OperaciÃ³n San Lorenzo"}}''.]] The original plan called for two rescue workers to descend into the mine before bringing the first miner to the surface. However, to avoid delay, rescuers decided to bring a miner to the surface in the returning capsule that had taken GonzÃ¡lez down. An "empty" trial run had taken place the previous day, with the capsule stopping just {{convert|15|m|ft|sp=us}} before the end of the shaft.[http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/national_world/stories/2010/10/12/trial-lowering-of-rescue-capsule-is-a-success.html "Trial lowering of rescue capsule is a success"], [[The Columbus Dispatch]], 12 October 2010; Retrieved 17 October 2010 After a further safety check, 15 minutes later miner Florencio Ãvalos began his ascent from the mine. TV cameras both inside the mine and on the surface captured the event and broadcast it worldwide. The mine's shift supervisor, Luis UrzÃºa, whose disciplined leadership was credited with keeping the men alive on an emergency food supply during their first 17 days without contact from the outside world, was the last miner to make the journey to the surface. {{cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/oct/08/trapped-chilean-miners-shaft-nears | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Sam | last1=Jones | first2=Jonathan | last2=Franklin | title=Trapped Chilean miners: rescue teams hope to start evacuation by Tuesday | date=8 October 2010}} Each transit of the capsule, whether up or down, was projected to take 15 minutes,[http://uk.news.yahoo.com/5/20101012/twl-live-chile-miners-rescue-begins-soon-3fd0ae9.html Live: Chile Miners Rescue Begins Soon]{{dead link|date=March 2011}} Sky News. 13 October 2010. Retrieved on 16 October 2010.{{Dead link|date=February 2011}} giving a total time of 33 hours for the rescue operation. In practice, after the capsule's first few transits, it became apparent that the trip might be shorter than the projected 15 minutes and each rescue cycle should take less than 1 hour. As the eighteenth miner was brought to the surface, Chilean Mining Minister Laurence Golborne stated "We have advanced at a faster time than we originally planned. I foresee we might conclude the whole operation before tonight."[http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Chile-Mine-Rescue-Begins-Operation-To-Pull-Trapped-Chilean-Miners-To-Safety-Under-Way/Article/201010215757107?lpos=World_News_News_Your_Way_Region_6&lid=NewsYourWay_ARTICLE_15757107_Chile_Mine_Rescue_Begins%3A_Operation_To_Pull_Trapped_Chilean_Miners_To_Safety_Under_Way Live: Chile Mine Rescue] Sky News, 13 October 2010. After stepping free from the rescuers and greeting his son, Luis UrzÃºa embraced President PiÃ±era saying, "I've delivered to you this shift of workers, as we agreed I would". The president replied, "I gladly receive your shift, because you completed your duty, leaving last like a good captain." President PiÃ±era went on to say "You are not the same after this, and Chile won't be the same either."[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2025624,00.html How the Miners Have Won Respect for Chile's Workers], Time Magazine, Tim Padgett, 14 October 2010 A large Chilean flag that had hung in the mine chamber during the rescue was brought up by Luis UrzÃºa. Once all the miners had been extracted, the rescuers in the mine chamber displayed a banner reading ''{{lang|es|"MisiÃ³n cumplida Chile"}}'' ("Mission accomplished Chile").[http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2010/10/101014_video_chile_mineros_rescate_vale2.shtml "Fin del rescate de los mineros: una epopeya con final feliz"] BBC News Mundo-Noticias, 14 October 2010 Manuel GonzÃ¡lez was the first rescuer down and the last up, spending 25 hours 14 minutes in the mine. Rescuers needing to sleep did so in the mine to avoid tying up the capsule on rescue-delaying journeys to the surface. When the last rescuer surfaced, President PiÃ±era covered the top of the rescue shaft with a metal lid. Altogether, ''FÃ©nix 2'' made 39 round trips, traveling a total distance of about {{convert|50|km|mi|sp=us}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11539784 |title=Lid is placed on Chile mine shaft |publisher=BBC News|date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2010}} ===Order of miners and rescuers=== [[File:San Jose Mina - Mision cumplida - screen capture.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Slightly grainy color video capture image of the six rescuers displaying the famous ''"Mision Cumplida Chile"'' sign deep within [[San JosÃ© Mine]] near Copiapo, Chile [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/misin-cumplida-chilean-miners-ordeal-comes-to-an-end-2106156.html MisiÃ³n cumplida: Chilean miners' ordeal comes to an end The Independent, London Guy Adams 14 October 2010]|The iconic image of the six rescuers displaying the famous ''"Mision Cumplida CHILE"'' (Mission Complete Chile) sign in [[San JosÃ© Mine]] near Copiapo, Chile ]] Before the rescue, the trapped miners were divided into three groups to determine their exit order. From first to last these were: ''{{lang|es|"hÃ¡biles"}}'' (skilled), ''{{lang|es|"lÃ¡biles"}}'' (weak) and ''{{lang|es|"fuertes"}}'' (strong).[http://www.elpais.com.uy/101012/ultmo-521431/ultimo-momento/hora-y-nombres-definidos-para-el-rescate Hora y nombres definidos para el rescate] El Pais, 12 October 2010 This grouping was based on the theory that the first men to exit should be those more skilled and in the best physical condition, as they would be better equipped to escape unaided in the event of a capsule malfunction or shaft collapse. They were also thought more able to communicate clearly any other problems to the surface rescue team. The second group included miners with medical problems, older men and those with psychological issues. The final group comprised the most mentally tough, as they had to be able to endure the anxiety of the wait;[http://www.prensalibre.com/internacionales/odisea/Rescate-mineros-chilenos-final-previsto_0_352764984.html Rescate mineros chilenos llega a fase final antes de lo previsto] PrensaLibre.com, 13 October 2010 in the words of Minister MaÃ±alich "they don't care to stay another 24 hours inside the mine". The exit order was as shown below. {{clear}} {| class="wikitable collapsible autocollapse" style="font-size: 95%" |- ! ! colspan="6"|Rescued miners (click "show" to expand the table) |- !Order Rescued !Miner's name !Age{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11170852 | work=BBC News | title=Jubilation as Chile mine rescue ends | date=13 October 2010}} !Rescue time ([[Time in Chile|CLDT]]) !Cycle time{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/9086813.stm |title=As it happened: Chile mine rescue|publisher=BBC News |date=13 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010}} !CommentsNick Allen [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8057102/Chile-miners-rescue-profiles-of-the-33-men.html Chile miners rescue: profiles of the 33 men], London Daily Telegraph, 12 October 2010 |- |1||Florencio Ãvalos||31||13 October 00:11||0:51||Recorded video footage to be sent up to families on the surface. He had helped to get his brother Renan a job in the mine. |- |2||Mario SepÃºlveda||40||13 October 01:10||1:00||An electrical specialist known as "the presenter" because he acted as a spokesman and guide on videos that the miners made. He ended one video with "Over to you in the studio." |- |3||Juan AndrÃ©s Illanes||52||13 October 02:07||0:57||A former Chilean Army corporal who served in the Beagle Conflict, a border dispute with neighboring Argentina. |- |4||Carlos Mamani||24||13 October 03:11||1:04||The only Bolivian among the 33, a heavy machinery operator who moved to Chile a decade ago. |- |5||Jimmy SÃ¡nchez||19||13 October 04:11||1:00||Given the responsibility of checking air quality[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/09/chilean-miners-typical-day] Chilean miners: A typical day in the life of a subterranean miner and the youngest man trapped. He had only been a miner for five months and had just had a baby daughter. |- |6||OsmÃ¡n Araya||30||13 October 05:35||1:24||In a video message he told his wife and baby daughter Britany: "I will fight to the end to be with you." |- |7||JosÃ© Ojeda||46|| 13 October 06:22||0:47||Penned the famous note "Estamos bien en el refugio, los 33" ("We are well in the shelter, the 33") which was discovered attached to a probe 17 days after the mine collapse.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11605409 Message which brought hope now copyright of Chile miner], BBC News, 20 October 2010 He is a grandfather who suffers from kidney problems and has been on medication for diabetes. |- |8||Claudio YÃ¡Ã±ez||34||13 October 07:04||0:42||A drill operator. His longtime partner Cristina NÃºÃ±ez accepted his marriage proposal while he was underground. |- |9||Mario GÃ³mez||63*||13 October 08:00||0:56||The eldest of the trapped miners, he had been thinking of retiring that November. (Note: *Multiple reliable sources have reported his age as between 60 and 65.) |- |10||Ãlex Vega||31||13 October 08:53||0:53||Suffers from kidney problems and hypertension. Had worked in the mine for nine years. |- |11||Jorge Galleguillos||56||13 October 09:31||0:38||Suffers from hypertension |- |12||Edison PeÃ±a||34||13 October 10:13||0:42||The group's song leader, he requested that Elvis Presley songs be sent down the mine. The fittest miner, he had reportedly been running {{Convert|10|km|sp=us}} a day while underground.
