The extraction times for the rescuers are correct but may be out of order and not listed next to the actual corresponding rescue worker. # "Down trip no." is the sequence number of the capsule journey that he was sent down on. ==Timeline of events== This is a general [[chronology]] of the events, from the beginning: * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|08|05|df=y}}|event=Rock-fall at the San JosÃ© mine in the [[Atacama Desert]] in northern Chile leaves 33 gold and copper miners trapped 2,300 feet below ground.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|08|07|df=y}}|event=Second collapse hampers rescue efforts and blocks access to lower parts of the mine. Rescuers begin drilling [[boreholes]] to send down listening devices.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|08|22|df=y}}|event=17 days after the first collapse, a note is found attached to one of the drill bits, saying: "33 of us have found a shelter and we are fine". The miners were in a shelter having lunch when the first collapse occurred, and had survived on rations. Food, medical supplies, clothes and bedding began to be sent down the borehole.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|08|27|df=y}}|event=The miners send first video greetings to the surface.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|08|30|df=y}}|event=First attempt to drill a hole to rescue the men, Plan A, begins.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|09|05|df=y}}|event=Plan B drilling begins.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|09|18|df=y}}|event=Miners celebrate [[Bicentennial of Chile|Chilean Bicentennial]] holiday underground.Philip Sherwell [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8011622/Trapped-Chilean-miners-celebrate-national-day-with-meat-pies-feast.html Trapped Chilean miners celebrate national day with meat pies feast], London Daily Telegraph, 18 September 2010}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|09|19|df=y}}|event=Plan C drilling begins.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|09|24|df=y}}|event=Miners had now been trapped underground for 50 days, longer than anyone else in history.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|09|df=y}}|event=Plan B drill breaks through to the miners' workshop.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|11|df=y}}|event=''{{lang|es|"FÃ©nix 2"}}'' rescue capsule is tested to ensure that it can pass up and down the newly completed shaft.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|12|df=y}}|event=Rescue begins at 23:20 [[Time in Chile|CLDT]].}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|13|df=y}}|event=At 21:56 [[Time in Chile|CLDT]] the last of the 33 miners is brought to the surface.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|14|df=y}}|event=First three miners released from hospital.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|15|df=y}}|event=28 more miners released from hospital, two remain for further treatment; dental and psychological follow-up.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|16|df=y}}|event=Mario SepÃºlveda discharged from hospital after additional psychological tests.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|19|df=y}}|event=VÃ­ctor Zamora released from hospital after serious dental surgery.}} * {{Timeline-event|date={{Start date|2010|10|25|df=y}}|event=Rescued miners honored at the ''{{lang|es|"[[La Moneda]]"}}'' presidential palace, met with President [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era]], posed for pictures with the ''{{lang|es|"FÃ©nix 2"}}'' capsule and played a friendly game of football against a government team at the [[Estadio Nacional Julio MartÃ­nez PrÃ¡danos|Julio MartÃ­nez PrÃ¡danos National Stadium]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11547889 Chile: First rescued miners leave hospital] BBC News, 15 October 2010.}} ==Reaction to the rescue== [[File:SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era - Reina Isabel.jpg|thumb|alt=Color image of Chilean President PiÃ±era and the First Lady present a souvenir gift rock from the San Jose Mine to Queen Elizabeth II on 18 October 2010 during a state visit to the UK|[[President PiÃ±era]] and First Lady present a souvenir rock from the mine to [[Queen Elizabeth II]] on 18 October 2010.]] {{Main|Reaction to the 2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident}} [[President of Chile|Chilean President]] [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era]] and First Lady [[Cecilia Morel]] were present during the rescue. [[President of Bolivia|Bolivian President]] [[Evo Morales]] was also scheduled to be there but did not arrive in time to see the rescue of the trapped Bolivian miner, Carlos Mamani.{{cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2010/oct/12/chilean-miners-rescue-live-coverage | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Mark | last1=Tran | first2=Matthew | last2=Weaver | first3=Adam | last3=Gabbatt | title=Chilean miners rescue â part 1 | date=12 October 2010}} Morales visited Mamani at a hospital along with PiÃ±era later in the day.{{cite news| url=http://mexico.cnn.com/mundo/2010/10/13/el-boliviano-carlos-mamani-recibe-la-visita-del-presidente-evo-morales | work=CNN | title=Pulso | date=13 October 2010}} A number of foreign leaders contacted PiÃ±era to express solidarity and pass on congratulations to Chile while rescue efforts were underway. They included the Presidents of [[Cristina FernÃ¡ndez de Kirchner|Argentina]], [[Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva|Brazil]], [[Juan Manuel Santos|Colombia]], [[Alan GarcÃ­a|Peru]], [[Jacob Zuma|South Africa]], [[JosÃ© Mujica|Uruguay]], [[Hugo ChÃ¡vez|Venezuela]],[http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/ultimas_noticias/2010/10/101013_ultnot_pinera_recibe_felicitaciones_mandatarios_pl.shtml Lula, ChÃ¡vez, Cristina FernÃ¡ndez y David Cameron felicitan a PiÃ±era] BBC News Mundo, 13 October 2010. (Spanish)[http://www.buanews.gov.za/news/10/10101408551001 Historic rescue completed], South African Government, 14 October 2010 and [[BronisÅaw Komorowski|Poland]],[http://www.president.pl/en/news/news/art,153,president-congratulates-chile.html President congratulates Chile] Prezydent.pl, 14 October 2010. as well as the Prime Ministers of the [[David Cameron|United Kingdom]],{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11536093 | work=BBC News | title=David Cameron congratulates Chilean President on rescue | date=13 October 2010}} [[JosÃ© Luis RodrÃ­guez Zapatero|Spain]] and [[Brian Cowen|Ireland]], (who also wrote personally to the Chilean president and the [[County Clare|Clare]]-based designers and manufacturers of the rescue drill).{{cite news | url = http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/cowen-congratulates-chile-on-rescue-operation-477634.html | work=BreakingNews.ie | title=Cowen congratulates Chile on rescue operation | date=14 October 2010}} Other foreign leaders including [[President of Mexico|Mexican President]] [[Felipe CalderÃ³n]][http://www.newkerala.com/news/world/fullnews-62059.html Celebrations erupt across Chile as first men emerge from mine] New Kerala, 13 October 2010 and [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]]{{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/14/world/americas/14obamachile.html | work=The New York Times | title=Obama Salutes Chile and Rescue | date=13 October 2010}} praised the rescue efforts and passed on their hopes and prayers to the miners and their families. [[Pope Benedict XVI]] left a video message in Spanish praying for the success of the rescue operation.[http://www.indcatholicnews.com/news.php?viewStory=16904 Pope prays for Chilean miners] Independent Catholic News, 13 October 2010 After the successful rescue, PiÃ±era gave a speech on location in which he praised Chile, saying that he was "proud to be the president of all Chileans." He invoked Chile's recently passed [[Bicentennial of Chile|Bicentennial]] celebrations and said that the miners were rescued with "unity, hope and faith." He thanked ChÃ¡vez and Morales, amongst others, for their calls of support and solidarity. He also said that those responsible for the collapse of the mine would be punished, and that there would be a "new deal" for the workers.Rory Carroll [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/oct/17/sebastian-pinera-luis-urzua-chile When the miners' leader met the president, two sides of Chile embraced], The Guardian, 17 October 2010[http://www.gobiernodechile.cl/destacados/2010/10/13/presidente-pinera-tras-el-rescate-de-los-33-mineros-chile-hoy-dia-esta-mas-unido-y-mas-fuer.htm Presidente PiÃ±era tras el rescate de los 33 mineros: "Chile hoy dÃ­a estÃ¡ mÃ¡s unido y mÃ¡s fuerte que nunca"] (Spanish), Chilean Presidential Web Site, Speech Extracts, 13 October 2010 ==Miners post-rescue== By 19 October, all 33 of the men had been released from the hospital. All but two of the men were allowed to go home within 48 hours of the rescue. Mario SepÃºlveda remained hospitalized for further psychological evaluation over concerns that he had yet to adapt to life outside the mine, but was released on 16 October.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8067501/Chile-miners-came-to-blows-but-swore-to-keep-details-secret.html Chile miners came to blows, but swore to keep details secret], London Daily Telegraph, Fiona Govan and Aislinn Laing, 15 October 2010 Meanwhile, VÃ­ctor Zamora remained to receive additional treatment for a dental infection and was released on 19 October.{{cite web|last=Raphael |first=Angie |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/freed-miners-return-to-camp-hope/story-e6frf7jx-1225939966063 |title=Freed miners return to Camp Hope|publisher=Herald Sun |date=18 October 2010 |accessdate=18 October 2010}}Philip Sherwell [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8068674/Chile-miners-new-battle-to-adapt-to-normality.html Chile miners' new battle to adapt to normality], London Daily Telegraph, 16 October 2010 ===Health concerns=== [[File:President PiÃ±era and miners in CopiapÃ³ Hospital.jpg|thumb|alt=Color image of President PiÃ±era visiting the rescued miners who are dressed in hospital robes and pajamas while seated and standing in a semi-circle in a hospital room|President PiÃ±era visiting the rescued miners in CopiapÃ³ Hospital in October 2010]] Doctors marveled at how well the men had coped physically with their time underground, but the media frenzy surrounding the men since their rescue concerned Chilean Health Minister, Jaime MaÃ±alich. He asked the media to treat the miners "with dignity and respect", adding that they needed "rest and repose" and a chance to come to terms with the events of the last 70 days. "They are still on an emotional roller-coaster". The medical team's psychologist, Alberto Iturra, warned that the miners were exhausted, "When that happens, your sensitivity rises to the maximum at the same time as your tolerance falls to almost nothing" he stated. Regardless of these issues, President PiÃ±era challenged the men to a friendly soccer game as well as inviting them to state functions including a visit to the presidential palace and the grand opening of a transcontinental highway.[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/1016/1224281251629.html Media carnival follows still vulnerable miners], Irish Times, 16 October 2010 Marc Siegel, an associate professor of medicine at the New York University [[NYU Langone Medical Center|Langone Medical Center]], said that lack of sunlight could potentially cause problems with muscles, bones and other organs. Jane Aubin, scientific director of the Institute of Musculoskeletal Health and Arthritis at the [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research|Canadian Institute for Health Research]], said the miners would have to be monitored closely. "They haven't been as physically active as you would want [them] to be, so they have undoubtedly experienced some muscle loss," she said. "Probably after that extended period of time, in both a confined space and in relative darkness, they've also probably experienced some [[Osteoporosis|bone loss]]."Caroline Alphonso [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/americas/miners-watched-closely-for-physical-and-mental-health-problems/article1758120 Miners watched closely for physical and mental health problems], Canada Globe and Mail, 15 October 2010 The team of psychologists who spoke to the miners daily in the mine will continue to follow their progress.{{Clarify|post-text=How long for? Are they still being monitored - source required|date=March 2011}} Officials considered canceling plans for a thanksgiving mass for the men and their families at ''Camp Hope'', on 17 October over fears that a premature return to the site could be damaging. "It's not a good idea that they go back to the mine so soon," said psychologist Iturra. Dr Jorge DÃ­az, head of the miners' medical team at CopiapÃ³ regional hospital said "We have a group of workers who are absolutely normal people, they weren't selected from a group of applicants to be astronauts, nor were they people who underwent rigorous tests, therefore we don't know when the [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress syndrome]] can appear." Conversely, [[post-traumatic growth]], positive psychological change experienced as a result of the struggle with highly challenging life circumstances could also result. The triumph of the miners in a highly challenging environment could also increase their self-confidence and strengthen bonds with each other and with their families. "When people are deprived ... it can be really adverse, it can really mess up a person. With these guys, they were together," said Charles Nelson, a psychologist with the operational stress injury clinic at Parkwood Hospital in London, Ontario, Peter Suedfeld, a professor emeritus at the [[University of British Columbia]], said the men are less likely to have trouble returning to their jobs. "Sailors who have been shipwrecked, for example ... many of them go back to sea," he said. "They'll feel that they can cope with anything that comes up." ===Activities=== On Sunday, 17 October 2010, six of the 33 rescued miners attended a [[multi-denominational]] memorial mass led by an evangelical pastor and a Roman Catholic priest at ''{{lang|es|"Campamento Esperanza"}}'' (Camp Hope) where anxious relatives had awaited the men's return. Some of the rescuers who helped bring the miners to the surface also attended.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11561355 Chile mine: Rescued men attend service of thanks], BBC News, 17 October 2010 Reporters and cameras mobbed the miners prompting the police to intervene to protect them. Omar Reygadas' family was swarmed by the media after they left the service and his 2-year-old great-granddaughter started crying when pushed by the crowd. As Reygadas picked her up the cameras zoomed in. Reygadas stayed calm but offered his only answer in response to their questions: "I've had nightmares these days," Reygadas said from inside a small tent while reporters jockeyed for position, "but the worst nightmare is all of you."[http://www.beijingtoday.com.cn/blogger/ahen/rescued-miners%E2%80%99-secrecy-pact-erodes-in-spotlight "Rescued Miners' Secrecy Pact Erodes in Spotlight"] - The New York Times - October 18, 2010 - Beijing Today - çæææ,ä¸¥ç¦è½¬è½½ Â· Copyright Â© 2008 Â· All Rights Reserved - retrieved Friday, November 26, 2010. Based on their experience, the miners plan to start a foundation to help in the field of mine safety. Yonni Barrios said "We're thinking about creating a foundation to solve [safety] problems in the mining industry. With this, with the experience that we had had, God help us, we should be able to solve these problems." Juan Illanes told El Mercurio "We have to decide how to direct our project so this type of thing never happens again. It needs to be done, but these things don't happen quickly".[http://www.smh.com.au/world/chile-miners-plan-mine-safety-group-20101018-16pct.html Chile miners plan mine safety group], The Sydney Morning Herald, Australia, 18 October 2010 On 24 October 2010, the miners attended a reception hosted by President PiÃ±era at the presidential palace in the capital, Santiago, and were awarded medals celebrating Chile's independence bicentennial. Outside, the men posed for photographs next to the Fenix rescue capsule that had winched them to the surface, now installed in the main square in Santiago. Afterwards, at the National Stadium, the freed miners played a football match against a team that included President PiÃ±era, Laurence Golborne the mining minister, and Jaime Manalich the health minister. Team ''{{lang|es|"Esperanza"}}'' (Hope), led by Franklin Lobos, all wore the number "33", but lost 3-2 to the government team.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8086413/Chiles-saved-miners-play-football-match-against-their-rescuers.htm Chile's saved miners play football match against their rescuers]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}, London Daily Telegraph, Fiona Govan, 25 October 2010{{Dead link|date=February 2011}} In November 2010, miners visited [[Los Angeles]], appearing in a taping of [[CNN]] "Heroes."[http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2010/11/chilean_miners_los_angeles.php "Chilean Miners Visit Los Angeles, Hollywood: CNN 'Heroes' Taping Planned"], Dennis Romero. Los Angeles Weekly. November 18, 2010. Accessed June 7, 2011 On 13 December 2010, 26 of the rescued miners, including [[Franklin Lobos]], went on invitation to a [[Manchester United]] training session at [[Carrington, Greater Manchester]] in England.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-11985807 | work=BBC News | title=Rescued Chile miners meet Manchester United players | date=13 December 2010}}}} In February 2011, 31 of the 33 miners were hosted by the [[Tourism Minister of Israel|Israeli Ministry of Tourism]] for an eight-day pilgrimage of Christian and Jewish holy sites.{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/VideoArticles/Video/Article.aspx?id=209466 |title=Chilean miners arrive for âpilgrimage of thanksâ |last=Lidman |first=Melanie |date=23 February 2011|accessdate=7 June 2011 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}} ==Legacy of the accident== [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Los 33 at Moneda Ceremony - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|thumb|alt=Color image of Los 33 miners attending a ceremony hosted by President PiÃ±era at the Presidential Palace on 24 October 2010 after their rescue from the San Jose Mine|''Los 33'' miners attending a ceremony hosted by President PiÃ±era at the Presidential Palace on 24 October 2010 after their rescue from the San Jose Mine]] ===Political=== Immediately following the San JosÃ© mine collapse, President PiÃ±era dismissed top officials from the ''[[Servicio Nacional de GeologÃ­a y MinerÃ­a de Chile]]'' (SERNAGEOMIN), Chile's mining regulatory agency and vowed to undertake a major overhaul of the department in light of the accident. In the days following the collapse, eighteen mines were shut down and a further 300 put under threat of possible closure. {{As of|2010|12}}{{cite news|title=Trapped Chilean miners face long shifts to keep their refuge clear of debris|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/26/trapped-chilean-miners-clear-debris| author = Franklin, Jonathan |publisher=The Guardian| date=26 August 2010|accessdate=27 August 2010 | location=London}} the San JosÃ© mine's long-term future is unclear; it is currently closed and will remain in limbo for an extended period as judicial processes are followed. On 25 October 2010, ahead of schedule, President PiÃ±era received a preliminary report by the Commission on Work Safety established in response to the incident. The report was a direct result of the CopiapÃ³ accident and contained 30 proposals ranging from improvements in hygiene to better coordination between local regulatory authorities. Although the commission had set November 22, 2010 as the date to deliver its final report, it reported that job safety inspections in Santiago and regions throughout Chile had allowed them to obtain a clear picture of the situation earlier than anticipated. In total, the commission held 204 hearings and reviewed 119 suggestions that came from online input. Throughout the incident, President PiÃ±era stressed that cost was of no object with regard to rescuing the miners. The operation was expensive with estimates surpassing US$20 million, excluding expenses in building, maintaining and securing ''{{lang|es|"Campamento Esperanza"}}'' (Camp Hope). These costs exceed the total business debt of the mine's owner, the San Esteban Mining Company, which currently stands at around US$19 million. The state mining company Codelco contributed about 75% to rescue costs with private companies donating services worth more than US$5 million.[http://www.santiagotimes.cl/news/other/19977-final-cost-for-chile-mine-rescue-is-tallied- Final Cost For Chile Mine Rescue Is Tallied], Santiago Times, Dominique Farrell, 13 October (English) [[File:Mina San JosÃ© - Los 33 in the Blue Room at Presidential Palace with President and First Lady - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb |alt=Color image of''Los 33'' miners posing with the President and First Lady of Chile in the Blue Room of the Presidential Palace on 24 October 2010|Los 33 miners posing with the President and First Lady of Chile in the Blue Room of the Presidential Palace on 24 October 2010]] The French credit rating agency [[Coface]] declared that the dramatic mining rescue will have a positive impact on Chile's economic reputation. "It provides to international investors an image of a country where you can do safe [sic] business," Coface's UK managing director, Xavier Denecker, said. "It gives a good impression in terms of technology, solidarity and efficiency." Coface rates countries according to the probability of private sector companies being successful. Chile holds its highest rating in South America: A2. The UK, in comparison, is rated at A3.[http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2010/oct/17/mining-rescue-chile-credit-rating Mining rescue lifts Chile's credit rating up into the light], The Guardian, London, Andrew Clark, 17 October 2010. ===Legal=== Following the accident, a lawsuit was filed against the San Esteban Mining Company by relatives of those trapped, while a judge froze US$2 million of its assets. A lawyer for several of the miners' families described this as a refutation of the company's claims of "not having even enough money to pay salaries". On 21 October, San Esteban Mining Company Operations Chief Carlos Pinilla and mine manager Pedro Simunovic issued a signed public statement insisting that no company official "had the slightest indication that a catastrophe could occur." Miner Jorge Gallardo asserted that there was no way the owners could have been unaware of the situation since he recorded everything and his daily safety reports were signed by Pinilla in person. Rescued miner Victor Zamora commented "What made me sad was that people were dying because the company did not want to have something safer and only thought about money".[http://www.santiagotimes.cl/news/human-rights/20056-chiles-commission-on-work-safety-delivers-preliminary-report-to-president-sebastian-pinera "Chile's Commission On Work Safety Delivers Preliminary Report To President SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era"], Written by Dominique Farrell, October 26, 2010. (English) ===Social=== [[HernÃ¡n Rivera Letelier]], a well known Chilean writer and former miner, wrote an article for the Spanish newspaper ''[[El Pais]]'' offering advice to the miners: "I hope that the avalanche of lights and cameras and flashes that is rushing towards you is a light one. It's true that you've survived a long season in hell, but, when all's said and done, it was a hell you knew. What's heading your way, now, comrades, is a hell that you have not experienced at all: the hell of the show, the alienating hell of TV sets. I've only got one thing to say to you, my friends: grab hold of your family. Don't let them go, don't let them out of your sight, don't waste them. Hold on to them as you hung on to the capsule that brought you out. It's the only way to survive this media deluge that's raining down on you."[http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2010/oct/18/chile-miners-global-media-coverage How the media in Chile helped focus the eyes of the world on the miners], The Guardian (UK), Rory Carroll, 18 October 2010. The UK ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that the miners have hired an accountant to ensure that any income from their new celebrity status is fairly divided, including money from expected book and film deals. The men have agreed to "speak as one" when they discuss their experiences. While still trapped, they appointed one of their group as official biographer and another their poet.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8066868/Chile-miners-will-speak-as-one.html Chile miners will 'speak as one'], London Daily Telegraph, Aislinn Laing, 15 October 2010 As of March 2011, the first of the expected books on the rescue, ''Under the Earth: The 33 Miners that Moved the World'' is nearing completion. Another book called ''33 Men, Buried Alive: The Inside Story of the Trapped Chilean Miners'', by [[Jonathan Franklin]], a writer for the UK-based ''[[The Guardian]]'', is due for release in early 2011.[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/chilean-miner-jose-ricardo-ojeda-vidal-copyrights-los-33/story-e6frg6so-1225942111686 Chilean miner Jose Ricardo Ojeda Vidal copyrights 'los 33'], The Australian, Martin Fletcher and Laura Dixon, 22 October 2010[http://entertainment.stv.tv/showbiz/202648-deals-already-on-offer-for-chilean-miners-story/ "Deals already on offer for Chilean miners' story"] - STV - Entertainment - October 14, 2010. The first of many expected TV documentaries was aired by [[NOVA]] on the US [[Public Broadcasting System]] on 26 October 2010.[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/tech/emergency-mine-rescue.html Emergency Mine Rescue: Engineers and NASA scientists aid an all-out effort to save 33 Chilean miners trapped nearly half a mile underground], NOVA (PBS), Aired October 26, 2010 ===Monument=== Chilean President SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era has suggested turning Camp Hope into a memorial or museum in honor of the men. The ''FÃ©nix 2'' capsule used in ''OperaciÃ³n San Lorenzo'' has been placed in the [[Plaza de la ConstituciÃ³n]], in front of Chile's presidential palace in Santiago, Chile. Currently, one of the backup capsules is in CopiapÃ³ and the other was sent to China for display in Chile's exhibit at the 2010 [[Shanghai Expo]]. Discussions are under way for a permanent display of the capsule and possibly a museum. {{As of |2010|12}}, potential locations include [[CopiapÃ³]], the city closest to the accident site, and [[Talcahuano]], {{convert|1,300|mi|km|sp=us}} to the south, where the capsules were built at a Chilean navy workshop.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/8070137/Chile-mine-rescue-towns-fight-over-Phoenix-2-capsule.html Chile mine rescue: towns fight over Phoenix 2 capsule], London Daily Telegraph, 18 October 2010 Since August 3, 2011, the ''FÃ©nix 2'' capsule is displayed at the Atacama Regional Museum in [[CopiapÃ³]].{{cite web| url=http://www.soychile.cl/Copiapo/Sociedad/2011/08/03/30302/Con-emocion-instalaron-la-capsula-Fenix-II-en-el-Museo-Regional-de-Atacama.aspx |title=Con emociÃ³n instalaron la cÃ¡psula FÃ©nix II en el Museo Regional de Atacama |author=Paul-Edouard Martin |work=[[El Diario de Atacama]] |date=August 3, 2011 |accessdate=August 13, 2011 |language=Spanish}} ==See also== {{Portal box|Chile|Mining|Disasters}} * [[Floyd Collins]] was a cave explorer who died after 14 days while trapped underground after a cave collapse in 1925. The accident scene quickly became a national media frenzy. * [[Kathy Fiscus]] was a young Californian toddler who died after falling down a well in 1949 and whose two day rescue attempt was broadcast live on radio and national TV. * [[Alfredo Rampi]] fell down a well and died as a six-year old in 1981 in Italy. The failed rescue attempt was broadcast live for 18 hours. * [[Jessica McClure]] was a Texas toddler who survived being trapped in a well for over two days in October, 1987, while the rescue operation was televised live on CNN. * [[Quecreek Mine Rescue]] involved a successful rescue attempt of adult, professional miners using a similar rescue capsule in Pennsylvania, July 2002, to rescue a trapped mining crew. * [[Beaconsfield Mine Collapse]]. In 2006, two Australian miners were rescued after two weeks underground. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}} ==External links== {{Multicol}} *{{wikinews-inline}} *{{Commons category-inline}}
